THE NEWS AND COURIER, Charleston, S. C, MONDAY MORNING, AUGUST 17,1942  Do You Know Your Charleston?  Port of Embarkation  N ARMY BEEHIVE OF WAR ACTIVITY-The Port of Embarkation at Charleston, under the command of Coone James T. Duke, shown at ower center, is one of the nation"s  most important miitary centers. , The .pictures above have been reeased for Publicat ion to inform, people of the community of some of the estabishment"s activities. At top  eft is an army signa corps night picture showing one of the ships being oaded from the docks with cargo destined for the fighting men abroad. The Port of Embarkation was  buit in the last war but since had faen into disrepair as is shown at top right. This picture was taken before work of restoring the miitary property was begun. At center eft  is shown the ength of the commodious warehouses and the broad apron of the dock. Top  right,  by  Reiy.]  Men and Materias Go in Vast Quantities to  Fighting Fronts from Jere  The Charleston Port of Embarkation is the spout of one of our  country"s gigantic funnes that are  pouring miions of tons of war  sinews into great ships, bound for  the four corners of the earth and  pying the waters of the seven seas.  The Port of Embarkation, then  known as the Port Terminas, was  constructed during the last war to  tacke a simper and less difficult  job of suppying the ships of our  A. E. F. Men and materia were  safey transported to the friendy  ports of France and England. Today  the war is not over there, but  everywhere.  Since those days, the base had  faen into a state of negect. Thousands of doars worth of Building  equipment and expensive machinery were corroding and rotting  in the sun and rain. Charleston  hoped that never again would there  be need for these erstwhie facilities for any but peacefu purposes.  A recent visit to the Port of Embarkation reveas starting and  dramatic changes. On entering the  cosey guarded gates of this vasty  enlarged miitary reservation, one  gets the feeling that here is an  active and vita part of our war  machine, running in high gear, with  an able staff of officers in command  of the various contros. Not one of  the gigantic war production plants  that I have had occasion to visit  during the last few months, and this  incudes wiow Run, brings home  the reaity of war as does this  Charleston cearing center for goba  tota warfare. This place was not  buiding ships but pumping the  bright red bood from our nation"s  heart to the punching, expoding  fists of our fighting forces, and  sending the suppies and materias  that eventuay will rip the vitas of  the Axis powers.  Barracks for Troops  Ordery groups of receliving barracks stand ready to sheter in comfort thousands of fighting men who  will pass through the port. Separated from these, but identica in  size and structure, are barracks for  negro troops. They will be given  equa comfort and recreationa facilities.  i In this section of the port our  sodiers will spend the last hours  before saiing time, far from home  and oved ones, and there will be  no brass bands nor waving hands  to cheer them off.  The quietness of this section  should be wecome to men who have  dedicated themseves to fight for  their country, whose minds must be  fied with the sober thoughts of  those who are about to go on a  journey to the unknown. It seems  fitting that the ships will pass out  to sea through batte-scarred  Charleston harbor, leaving Fort  Sumter to starboard, Fort Moutrie  to port. Perhaps the hovering spirits  over those old forts will breath a  prayer of godspeed and encouragement for this new generaltion of  batte-bound warriors.  Escorted by an armed guard, the  visitor passes through a abyrinth of  grim green materia on whees. On  and that weeks ago was a swamp  stood countess rows of things  which are going to make history.  Puffing ocomotives were shunting  fat cars oaded with ugy but comforting ooking burdens that were  the awe-compeing products we see  pictured and advertised in our  monthy and weeky magazines.  Here were the products of Ford,  general Motors, Chryser and the  hundreds of great manufacturing  plants from every part of our nation.  Great Warehouses Fied  One crosses tracks that fan out to  rows and rows of neaty buit warehouses, a quarter of a mie in  ength and a bock in width. These  buildings are pied high with thousands of items that our war machine needs from Iceand to India,  and down under the word to Austraia: items such as drums of  drinking water for places where  water may mean life or death; uniforms, canned and dehydrated foods,  medica suppias, bacon, cheese,  prime ribs of beef, mosquito nets  and fy swatters. Enough indeed  to fill two Sears, Roebuck cataogues. It is more monthy tonnage  than    is received    by the    city of  Charleston and the navy yard combined.  At the foot of these great storehouses ies the ong concrete wharf,  capable of loading several ships at  a time, which soon will be enlarged  so as to handle and load an unstated number of ships that will be  coming to the Great Port of  Charleston in ever increasing numbers.  This end of the port is of most  obvious interest. One gets the impression of extreme but ordery  haste; that these ships have been  expected, and their loading carefully planned. It seems hard to  believe that the peacefuy flowing  river, which not so ong ago was  the means of travel for the city-  bound plantation owner, has now  become the watery path to the most  devastating and boody war in history.  I watched a hooded gang of weders securing to the decks gracefu-  ooking objects that never were designed to be carried on a ship.  The  Commanding   Officer  The more I saw, the more anxious I became to meet the directing  brains of this great war-time beehive, Coone James T. Duke, commanding officer.  Coone Duke was born in Maryand in 1893 and has spent most of  his miitary life in the cavary service. He instructed at the cavary  School at Fort Riey, Kansas, for  tweve years, and distinguished  himsef in this branch of the service. He also is a graduate of the  French Ecoe d" Appicacion de  Cavaerie in 1928. He is a graduate  of the Command and general Staff  School of eavenworth, Kansas, and  of the Army industrial College at  Washington. He recenty was G2  of the army ground force in Washington, under general esie Mc-  Nair, and was especiay appointed  by Washington to take command of  the Charleston Port of Embarkation.  He is an officer who believes in  strict discipine. His wide, aert  eyes seem to be ooking for bottenecks and troube. He took me on  a tour of the port that included the  boarding of a loading ship. His presence is felt by everyone. He toerates no soppy, unmiitary methods. He seems to turn up at places  where he is not expected.  He is a man of inquisitive energy,  who needs to see things for himsef and not just read reports. He  fees that his job and the job of the  men under him is every bit as important as that of the sodier on the  front Line of batte.  Wants Things Done  "without suppies deivered at the  right time an army is useess," he  said. He wants to get things done  today and not tomorrow. He believes in knowing the leading people of Charleston and etting them  know about his problems and earning about theirs. He has studied the  desperatey inadequate housing situation for the miitary and civiian workers, and is trying to reieve  it by every means possibe. He is  dipomatic, a good istener and a  good taker. Aways he impresses  people as a man who is getting  things done and  done in a hurry,  that there is a war to be won. He  has a responsibiity that would  daunt many a business man who  has first to consider profit.  Coone Duke"s profit is the saving of time and deivering the  goods. He is a cavary man sitting  firmy in the Port of Embarkation  sadde, and he has a tight grip on  the reins.  Coone H. J. Farner, second in  command, takes as much of the  load of paper work off Coone  Duke"s shoulders as he can. This  gives Coone Duke the opportunity  to devote his time to inspect and  supervision. Coone Farner"s work  corresponds to the eader of a  bocking section on a footba team.  He is ready at a times to take  fu command when Coone Duke  has to be away. Coone Farner is  a ta man who looks very calm  and probably is not.  Simpson Buit Fort Bragg  Coone . . Simpson, port  transportation officer, is the construction engineer who six months  ago planned the smoothy functioning port. He is in chlarge of incoming and outgoing freight, and  its storage. He hires a civiian  crew of 3,000 with a payro of  $3,000,000 a year.  He is a native of wimington, N.  C. He  is technical adviser to Coone  Duke on a transportation matters  for troops by rai, motor or air. He  has defined the mission of the port  in this simpe sentence: "To receive materia and personne for  overseas shipment". His responsibiity is vast.  Major ouis Barteoni, superintendent of the Army Transport  Service, has another important key  post. He has to load everything to  be transported.  He has chlarge of a stevedoring  and repairs, the inspection, stocking and loading of troopships, and  the assigning of staterooms and  compartments.  On the commanding officer"s staff  he has chlarge of a piers and protection and recording of a suppies  and cargoes. He is responsibe for  water transportation in and out of  the Port of Charleston. He has been  in the army for thirty-one years  and rose from the ranks.  $30,000,000  a  Month  ieutenant Coone William I. C, to Key West, including Mobie and part of the state of Georgia. He pays on an average of $20,-  000,000 to $30,000,000 a month and  last month drew more than 25,000  checks. The ist is too ong for this artice,  but mention must be made of ieutenant Coone Emer S. Van Ben-  scoten, adjutant, a fied artiery of  ficer who has much of the detai  work to do for the commander. A  chat with this coone revealed a  mind of deep-seated knowledge and  an officer who has found time for  extensive reading.  He was born in New Jersey in  1887.  Major F. W.
